comment.body:
> Still on my list of things to do, hopefully this week!

Great!  Happy to help where I can and test implementation.  Have been working with Falcon for a while now.  

All the best Stephen

issue.title: Use cpu_features instead of __builtin_cpu
issue.body: FMA4 and SSE4A detection is not supported by the library. Additionally enables NEON detection in Picnic

comment.body:
Adding a compiler to Linux CI images may solve the problem, but the library requires it by mistake, it is successfully built without it.
```
[archie@archlinux build]$ cmake .. -GNinja

[5/9] /usr/bin/cc -DSTACK_LINE_READER_BUFFER_SIZE=1024 -I../include -I../include/internal -O3 -DNDEBUG   -std=gnu99 -MD -MT CMakeFiles/utils.dir/src/string_view.c.o -MF CMakeFiles/utils.dir/src/string_view.c.o.d -o CMakeFiles/utils.dir/src/string_view.c.o   -c ../src/string_view.c
[6/9] /usr/bin/cc -DSTACK_LINE_READER_BUFFER_SIZE=1024 -I../include -O3 -DNDEBUG   -std=gnu99 -MD -MT CMakeFiles/list_cpu_features.dir/src/utils/list_cpu_features.c.o -MF CMakeFiles/list_cpu_features.dir/src/utils/list_cpu_features.c.o.d -o CMakeFiles/list_cpu_features.dir/src/utils/list_cpu_features.c.o   -c ../src/utils/list_cpu_features.c
[7/9] /usr/bin/cc -DSTACK_LINE_READER_BUFFER_SIZE=1024 -I../include -I../include/internal -O3 -DNDEBUG   -std=gnu99 -MD -MT CMakeFiles/cpu_features.dir/src/cpuinfo_x86.c.o -MF CMakeFiles/cpu_features.dir/src/cpuinfo_x86.c.o.d -o CMakeFiles/cpu_features.dir/src/cpuinfo_x86.c.o   -c ../src/cpuinfo_x86.c
[8/9] : && /usr/bin/cmake -E remove libcpu_features.a && /usr/bin/ar qc libcpu_features.a  CMakeFiles/utils.dir/src/filesystem.c.o CMakeFiles/utils.dir/src/stack_line_reader.c.o CMakeFiles/utils.dir/src/string_view.c.o CMakeFiles/cpu_features.dir/src/cpuinfo_x86.c.o && /usr/bin/ranlib libcpu_features.a && :
[9/9] : && /usr/bin/cc -O3 -DNDEBUG  -rdynamic CMakeFiles/list_cpu_features.dir/src/utils/list_cpu_features.c.o  -o list_cpu_features  libcpu_features.a  -ldl && :
```
I opened the issue https://github.com/google/cpu_features/issues/109. Maybe we should just wait for the fix? I can also try to add FMA4 and SSE4A support to their library.

issue.title: Use cpu_features instead of __builtin_cpu
issue.body: FMA4 and SSE4A detection is not supported by the library. Additionally enables NEON detection in Picnic

comment.body: One way or another, all checks have passed now :-) @gadoofou87 if you'd have time, sure, more CPU feature support is always good. If you know that lib somewhat (?) it'd also be great if you could maybe take a look at [cpu_features issue 108](https://github.com/google/cpu_features/issues/108) which is blocking shared-lib usage of `cpu_features`.

issue.title: Speed support
issue.body:
Resolves #35 . Due to some memory issues apparently triggered by picnic, testing is slightly limited. As discussed, a new issue for this will be raised.

##### Checklist
- [X] documentation is added or updated
- [X] tests are added or updated

comment.body: I couldn't see any obvious memory errors. Go ahead with merge and then let's create an issue to track it.

issue.title: Use cpu_features instead of __builtin_cpu
issue.body: FMA4 and SSE4A detection is not supported by the library. Additionally enables NEON detection in Picnic

comment.body:
I think we should use `add_subdirectory` instead of `find_package` or `ExternalProject_Add ` since that's also what's recommended [here](https://github.com/google/cpu_features/blob/master/cmake/README.md).

It also (sadly) seems like the best way to include the project would be to copy the source over verbatim, maybe with a script to fetch a new version every so often.

issue.title: How to choose algortihm for KEX/GEM of my choice?
issue.body:
It is unclear, and seemingly impossible after trying hard, to select a quantum algorithm for KEM/KEX of my choice, or at all for that matter. The example given with the internal TLS server/client designed for testing works like a charm, but if I wanted to choose a quantum algorithm for KEM/KEX say for a vpn, or generate the parameters to use one for a configuration file, there seems to be no way of doing this. With the OQS-Openssl_1.0.2 one can specify the ciphersuite and that takes care of it because in that version the ciphersuite definition includes the KEM/KEX, but in OpenSSL 1.1.1 KEM/KEX is no longer in the ciphersuite, and creating "curves" for the Qalgorithms using the OpenSSL API for EC is no go. 

Even the demos for nginx/curl/httpd do not mention how to choose one over the others. Could you please advice on how to do this?

Thank you.

comment.body:
> What needs to be done to make OpenVPN work with the TLS1.3 OpenSSL 1.1.1 fork?

This is on the list of things to investigate...

issue.title: Use cpu_features instead of __builtin_cpu
issue.body: FMA4 and SSE4A detection is not supported by the library. Additionally enables NEON detection in Picnic

comment.body: This is recommended, but we cannot use `add_subdirectory` because we need to build `cpu_features` before running `list-cpu-extensions.c`. I also don't understand why we can't use `ExternalProject_Add` if it works correctly?

issue.title: How to choose algortihm for KEX/GEM of my choice?
issue.body:
It is unclear, and seemingly impossible after trying hard, to select a quantum algorithm for KEM/KEX of my choice, or at all for that matter. The example given with the internal TLS server/client designed for testing works like a charm, but if I wanted to choose a quantum algorithm for KEM/KEX say for a vpn, or generate the parameters to use one for a configuration file, there seems to be no way of doing this. With the OQS-Openssl_1.0.2 one can specify the ciphersuite and that takes care of it because in that version the ciphersuite definition includes the KEM/KEX, but in OpenSSL 1.1.1 KEM/KEX is no longer in the ciphersuite, and creating "curves" for the Qalgorithms using the OpenSSL API for EC is no go. 

Even the demos for nginx/curl/httpd do not mention how to choose one over the others. Could you please advice on how to do this?

Thank you.

comment.body:
Update: The reason I was not able to see the nginx traffic is silly...it turns out you have to enable docker containers to have access to your network, else all traffic is internal to docker. So open ports to the outside world with ``-p hostport:containerport`` or the whole thing with ``--network host``. After that I was able to see the nginx traffic and it looks fine for nginx.

@christianpaquin why can't we have nice things that just work? :(
